Award.AwardTitle: Ramping Up Accessibility in STEM: Inclusively Designed Simulations for Diverse Learners

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ramping Up Accessibility in STEM: Inclusively Designed Physics Education Technology (PhET) Simulations for Diverse Learners

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This project will bring together leaders in simulation design and accessibility to develop and study interactive science simulations for diverse middle school students including those with sensory, mobility, or learning disabilities. The resulting simulations and research findings will help to address the significant disparity that exists between the achievement in science by students with and without disabilities. The Physics Education Technology (PhET) Interactive Simulations project (University of Colorado Boulder) will develop and research interactive science and math simulations used by teachers and students around the world. The Inclusive Design Research Centre (OCAD University, Toronto, Ontario) is an international leader in inclusively designed technology, with the goal of designing for the full range of human diversity including those with and without disabilities. Together, the project team will engage in an iterative design process to develop innovative solutions for making the highly interactive environment of an educational simulation simultaneously intuitive, accessible, and supportive of exploration and discovery practices in science. Development efforts will focus on three inclusive simulations and optimize the design and implementation of several inclusive simulation features, including keyboard navigation, auditory descriptions for screen readers, the use of non-speech sounds to provide feedback (sonification), and the ability to control the simulation with assistive technology (AT) devices. For each simulation, professional development materials for teachers, including classroom activities and user guides, will be developed to support teachers in effectively using the inclusively designed simulations in their classrooms.

Through new research, this project will seek to understand: 1) how inclusive simulations can support students with disabilities to engage in science practices, 2) how students with and without disabilities utilize inclusive simulations for learning STEM content, and 3) how students can engage in collaborative learning between students with and without disabilities - with an inclusive simulation. Researchers will use individual interviews with diverse students to closely examine these questions. The resulting resources, models, and tools will provide exemplars and important building blocks for an inclusively designed interactive curriculum, educational games, and assessment tools. Resulting simulations, research findings, design guidelines, and exemplars will be disseminated through the project team and advisor partner networks, education resource websites, and educator professional organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PhET Interactive Simulations project is an educational technology research and development group at the University of Colorado Boulder. The PhET project has conducted research on simulation design and development, and teaching and learning with simulations since 2002, while also disseminating a suite of free high-quality interactive simulations and associated teacher resources to advance STEM learning around the world. The full suite of PhET resources includes over 160 free and openly licensed interactive simulations with associated teaching resources, and an open source technical infrastructure for interactive learning resources. The simulations are run more than 80 million times per year worldwide, across K-16 levels, and have been translated into 90 languages.

Through NSF DRL-1503439 Ramping up Accessibility in STEM: Inclusively Designed PhET Simulations for Diverse Learners, the PhET team was able to collaborate with leaders in digital accessibility and inclusive design to advance foundational understanding of the design, development, and research of accessible simulations to support learners with disabilities. Students with disabilities often have reduced opportunities for experiential learning, a foundational component of a high-quality STEM education, and teachers often struggle to adapt inquiry-based materials to students' needs. Accessibility features, such as auditory descriptions and alternative input (e.g., keyboard control) can provide much needed access to these educational technologies. Unfortunately, there exist significant barriers to accessibility for interactive learning resources. With this project, we contributed to the broadening of participation in STEM by learners with disabilities by investigating ways learners with disabilities can utilize interactive technologies, innovating solutions to technical and design challenges that limit accessibility of interactive learning resources, and publishing free and highly accessible interactive physics simulations for teaching and learning. 

Central to the project activities is the advancement of foundational research on inclusive and accessible technologies, and their use and effectiveness with learners with disabilities. In our research, we conducted 32 think-aloud interviews with learners with disabilities. Think-aloud interviews provide researchers with in-depth moment-by-moment information into the thought, decision making, and learning processes during technology use. Through analysis of interview data, we investigated the diversity of technologies used, developed a model of learner strategies employed, identified requirements for robust access supporting student agency and learning, refined prototype accessibility features, and advanced understanding of opportunities for interactive resources to scaffold learning. 

Utilizing this knowledge, we designed and developed accessibility features for a collection of PhET simulations. We published six simulations with advanced alternative input capabilities (such as keyboard accessibility), which supports access by learners with sensory or mobility impairments. To accomplish this, we needed to address the unique needs of educational resources with an array of non-standard features such as interactive arms, legs, atoms, neutrons, and balloons. Additionally, we developed a description framework for complex interactives, which supports the creation of a modular system of descriptions capable of providing a rich non-visual learning experience with highly visual simulations. In parallel to the description framework, we developed a novel technical approach (the Parallel Document Object Model) that allows the description framework to be implemented seamlessly into the simulation's software architecture. Using the description framework and associated software architecture, interactive simulations can be made accessible to learners who are visually impaired. We have since published four simulations with both alternative input and auditory description features. These simulations include John Travoltage, Balloons and Static Electricity, Friction, and Resistance in a Wire.

Throughout this work, we utilized an inclusive design approach, iteratively incorporating data and feedback collected from learners with disabilities, special education teachers, accessibility specialists, as well as STEM teachers, science content experts, and simulation designers. The PhET team and collaborators at OCAD University gained new insights and expertise into effective inclusive design practices. In the process we developed and refined effective practices to collect, analyze, and synthesize data and feedback from diverse learners and use these findings to inform design across auditory description, traditional and alternative input, and multiple interaction pathways. 

During this NSF grant, the project team disseminated findings, knowledge, exemplars, best practices, and also developed open source software. We reached teacher, accessibility, education technology, and education research communities through: multiple collaborations; 6 publications; 1 book chapter; an undergraduate honors thesis and masters research project; 21 conference presentations; 2 webinars; the NSF "STEM For All" video showcase (winning Facilitators Choice & Public Choice Awards); the PhET accessibility website page with video introduction to accessibility features; and social media. More than two dozen researchers, developers, and students contributed to this research, and over forty learners with disabilities were included in the research and design process. Outcomes of this project will serve as critical building blocks for the future of accessible interactive learning resources, educational games, and assessment tools, and the inclusion of people with disabilities in STEM.
